titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Thursday May 5th: Long intervals occur between the days of which I give any account. It is not that my pen would be at a loss for materials of narrative or description much more frequently. But business, pleasure, and above all indolence often wrest it from my hands.

Spent this evening at the Miss Amory’s. Two Miss Lowell’s, Miss Barbara Higginson. Two Miss Russell’s, Miss Betsey Amory were the Ladies. Two Mr: Higginson’s, Mr: Bowen, Mr: Deblois, Mr Crafts, Captn: Hubbard, Mr: Blake, Mr: Lowell, Mr: Callender the gentlemen; besides Jonathan Amory, who was a kind of stranger at home. The evening was not very bright. Music as usual, vocal and instrumental, was the most pleasing part of the entertainment.

These companies composed altogether of young people unmarried of both sexes, are the most insipid of all the parties, where there is no particular sentiment to make them interesting. When they are much frequented it becomes absolutely necessary to make some selection and to depend for the amusement of the time upon some individual. How languid is indifference!
